The nineties were characterized by a phenomenon I call bitchification. Any women covered by the news was maligned, objectified, dismissed, often with the owrd bitch
we have so much to gain from a fresh look or the very least an honest appraisal of the nineties. We must or we risk repeating the mistakes of the past.
The stories of nineties women have become sexist mythology. A problematic hsitory, that saps women of their power, just as it was intended to do.
We are still experiencing the after shocks. The Clinton impeachement scandal, then covered as the Monica Lewinsky scandal, cast Lewinsky as a blow job queen.
During the OJ Simpson trial, lawyer Marcia Clark was framed as an unqualified teenager and a bad mom
Anita Hill testifies that supreme court nominie Clarence Thomas sexually harrased her. Hill was called a scorned women and a litle bit nutty and a litle bit slutty
The media revolution of the twenty four hour news cycle focused on these storeis and insatiable audience followed. Women quickly became renetless content.
Lorena Bobbitt cut off her husbands penis, after alleged years of rape and abuse.
The press mocked her. Celebrated him and covered her as a perpetrator, not a victim
History has remembered these women negatively. The medias bitchification didn't treat all women equally.
While white women face sexism, black women face racism and sexism.
Black women were portrayed as jezebels and sapphires. Hypersexual, angry or threatening, because of their race.
The media that bitchified women back then and continue to bitchify women today, must be held accountable.
This is an ongoing process. Progress is that women more are telling their own stories today.
A new documentary called Lorena recognizes that she is a survivor of domestic abuse and an immigrant women.
A hearting biopic, humanizes her by juxtaposing her accomplishment, with hardship she suffered
Today we are faced with a very differnet media revolution, the social media revolution.
Through the lens of metoo and timesup, we can see the harm that media caused.
And while the internet can be a harsh place for women, it is also home to supportive spaces for survivors, viral campaigns to fight injustice.
It helps us see, that we are not alone. Others are fighting with us.
Recent laws passed by the indian parliament are set to irrevocably damage indian democracy and constitutional framework.
Government revoked the autonomy of provinces of Jammu and Kashmir. Phone and internet are cut off this instance. Key political leaders are detained.
This paves the way for hindu indian settlements in kashmir to change the demographic set up of the region
Since its inception, Israel has used jewish only settlements, to supplant local palestinian commuinities that are being expelled from their land.
Indias new citizenship law grants minorities form neighbouring countries citizenship as long as they are not muslims
The law of return, a central pillar of Israel's apartheid regime grants only jew citizenship, but bars even palestinian refugees right to return.
Agriculture, universities and bollywood have become testing grounds and propoganda spaces
Our opressors are connected, but our movements united can defeat them.
The white british population has decreased by six hundered thousand. While the minority population has increased by one twenty million. Yes lads, we are winning.

In less than two minutes, we are gonna teach you about the racist history of so called right to work. What it is, where it exists and how we can defeat it.
It's primary purpose is to destroy labour union and the freedom of collective bargaining.
Dividing workers by race has been essential to thwarting labour organizing efforts since the days of slavery.
The biggest proponent of the right to work was an anti semitic, white supremacist, corporate lobbyist, named vance muse.
Mr. Muse was terrified, labour organizers in the south might get balck and white workers to join the same unions.
A number of states have gone so far as to even make it right to work a part of their state constitution.
Where ever these laws exist, wages are lower, benefits for workers are worse, job-site safety and worker protections are poor and workers freedom is nearly not existent.
In our glorious fight for civil rights, we must guard against being pulled by false slogans such as right to work.
But we can do more than just play defence. We can and must go on the offensive. By passing the passing the PRO act for example, we could overwrite right to work laws all across the country.
Right to work was racist in its origins and it attacks on public sector unions, which are strongly represented by workers of color remain fundamentally racist.
Let's put right to work into the dustbin of history, where it belongs, once and for all
